keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including Customs and Border Protection and ICE, are under judicial scrutiny for allegedly violating a judge’s order to restrict the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago.
Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order requiring agents to wear body-worn cameras and prohibiting the use of tear gas and other crowd control tactics without warning.
The Trump administration has defended its actions, denying reports of tear gas deployment without warning, though officials acknowledged they have not personally witnessed such incidents.
Despite the order, agents were reportedly using tear gas and pepper balls, prompting Judge Ellis to express serious concerns that her directives are not being followed.

Operation Midway Blitz, a Trump administration immigration crackdown targeting migrants in Chicagoland, has led to widespread protests, including over 100 demonstrators at the Broadview ICE facility, with 15 arrests on Friday and another 15 on Saturday.

The judge has ordered that the interim head of ICE in Chicago, Russell Hott, and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino be deposed later, emphasizing that Hott, as the highest-ranking official, must provide insight into the events.
Federal officials claimed that Border Patrol personnel were primarily involved in the tear gas incidents, and Harvick, the Deputy Incident Commander, was deemed the most appropriate to testify.
The judge stressed that if officials cannot provide clear answers, she will request further testimony until she receives the information she needs.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge, Sara Ellis, is demanding accountability from federal agencies, including Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for allegedly violating her order to restrict the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests against immigration enforcement in Chicago. The controversy stems from Operation Midway Blitz, a Trump administration-led crackdown that resulted in over 1,000 arrests in Illinois between September 8 and October 3, 2025. Despite promises of compliance, Judge Ellis expressed serious concerns that her directives—such as requiring body-worn cameras and banning unannounced deployment of tear gas—are not being followed. Officials including Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers testified, denying reports of tear gas use without warning, though they acknowledged not having personally witnessed such incidents. The judge has mandated that key officials, such as former ICE Chicago head Russell Hott and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino, be deposed to provide full context. Protests at the Broadview ICE facility have continued, with over 100 demonstrators and 30 arrests reported, highlighting public resistance to immigration enforcement. The case underscores the tension between federal executive power and judicial oversight in policing civil dissent.
title: Federal officials try to reassure judge they’re following her orders to tone down and record Chicagoland protest actions
